nodes.text: Machine learning can provide novel insights and opportunities to solve important challenges in reliability engineering and safety, leading to more accurate analysis, better decision-making, and improved accident prevention
The literature on ML for reliability and safety is large but fragmented and difficult to navigate, motivating a synthesis and roadmap
Machine learning categories relevant to reliability and safety include supervised, unsupervised, semi-supervised, and reinforcement learning, each with characteristic tasks, models, and trade-offs

Supervised methods: regression and classification are used for RUL estimation, degradation prediction, and fault identification using models such as SVR, GPR, decision trees, random forest, and neural networks

Unsupervised methods: clustering and anomaly detection discover patterns and unexpected observations in unlabeled data using K-means, hierarchical clustering, SOM, OC-SVM, autoencoders and related algorithms

Semi-supervised and reinforcement learning: SSL leverages small labeled and large unlabeled datasets (graph-based, S3VM, generative models); RL and deep RL learn policies from interaction and enable condition-based maintenance and large-scale inspection scheduling; safe RL incorporates safety constraints during learning

Supervised application results: ML methods have been applied successfully to remaining useful life estimation and degradation prediction across domains (batteries, bearings, engines), and to classification for fault detection and PHM with improved accuracy and computational efficiency in many studies

Unsupervised/anomaly detection results: ML anomaly detection methods support early fault detection and PHM in gas turbines, motors, wind turbines, aircraft flight data and structures, often enabling detection from raw streaming sensor data

Spacecraft anomaly detection is a challenging application: many anomalies are contextual, labeled data are scarce, OOL threshold methods miss context anomalies, and ML (OC-SVM, LSTM) shows promise but suffers high false alarm rates that hinder operations adoption

Deep learning is a distinct subset of ML with hierarchical feature extraction that handles high-dimensional, nonlinear problems and has demonstrated superior performance in many PHM and anomaly detection tasks

Evidence that deep models (CNN, LSTM, autoencoders, DBN) outperform shallow models includes higher RUL accuracy, robust raw-signal anomaly detection, and better handling of temporal and high-dimensional sensor data in multiple published studies

There are several high-value future opportunities for ML to advance reliability and safety across deployment, fleet- and system-of-systems PHM, data integration, wearable-based predictive safety, and advanced probabilistic generative models

Uncertainty quantification and reduction, and deployment considerations: ML applications must provide uncertainty estimates (confidence intervals, sources of uncertainty) and address false alarm trade-offs to enable operational adoption

Fleet-level and system-of-systems PHM: ML should be extended from component-level to fleet and system-of-systems contexts (e.g., satellite constellations, wind farms), leveraging transfer learning and integrating with systems engineering and human factors

Integration opportunities: apply ML to accident and near-miss databases and safety management systems, and integrate ML with wearable sensors and body-cameras for predictive safety analytics and injury prevention

Advanced models recommendation: deep Gaussian processes and generative adversarial networks are promising tools for improved uncertainty-aware surrogate modeling, data augmentation, and realistic high-dimensional modeling in reliability and safety applications
